title: File chapter 7 can i refirm the 1st deed and put the 2nd deed in to the bankruptcy on my rental home
question: i have a house (rental) i was told by my bank that i could put the 2nd into the bankruptcy and refirm the 1st. my att. said i must refirm both deeds in order to keep the home .which is right?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Lien,Deficiency balance,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Tax law
answers:
I disagree with your attorney and the answer posted above. I have handled hundreds and hundreds of cases in San Diego and not once have I advised a client to sign a reaffirmation agreement with respect to real estate. The only reason in your case to even entertain a reaffirmation agreement on your first is if they are offering to cancel the second trust deed (assuming it is with the same lender-post is kind of confusing where you say bank said you could put second into bankruptcy but need to reaffirm the first). I would NEVER recommend a client sign a reaffirmation agreement on real estate absent extraordinary circumstances such as described above. Once you sign the agreement and it is filed with the court (no court approval is necessary for reaffirmation of real estate), you are back on the hook for the debt and if you default in the future you can be sued. There is no downside if you simply continue to pay the mortgage as you have done in the past and not sign the agreement. If for some reason you default in the future, your lender can only take the property back and CANNOT sue you for any deficiency balance as they can if you do sign a reaffirmation agreement. Again, unless they are agreeing to cancel the second trust deed, significantly reduce interest or principal, or some other HUGE benefit to you, advising a client to sign a reaffirmation agreement on real estate is very ill-advised in my opinion.

Under a chapter 7, you would need to reaffirm (or at the very least continue to pay) your first and second loans to keep the house. Under a chapter 13, if your 1st loan exceeds the current value of your home, you can have the 2nd lien stripped. I am thinking the bank thought you were filing a chapter 13 or that the person at the bank (generally not a lawyer) doesn't understand the differences in types of bankruptcies.
